title: Handling the News of Being Diagnosed With a Chronic Condition

content: Have you ever sat in a doctor’s office, nervously waiting for them to share what your gut tells you is bad news? Your heart was probably pounding, and you couldn’t stop your hands and legs from shaking. I know the feeling firsthand.

In 2018, my doctor informed me that I had developed prediabetes and was at risk of later developing type 2 diabetes. In that cold office, he warned me about the other potential complications: high blood pressure and heart disease. He was straight with me. Unfortunately, I failed to take his advice seriously enough to make immediate changes. So at 268 pounds, the heaviest I had ever been, my attitude was, “Well, at least I don’t have full-blown type 2 diabetes. So I’m good.”

Fast forward. The consequences of disregarding my health became evident by August 2020 when I found myself in a hospital bed, receiving the diagnosis that I had finally developed type 2. Dang! There I was: A diabetic person. Overweight, stressed, fatigued, dehydrated, and being pumped full of meds to stabilize my condition. My hospital stay led me to contemplate my life, its purpose, and how I almost died. Real talk.

content: So if you’re in a similar situation, know that I understand what you're going through. It's natural to feel overwhelmed, shocked, and even in disbelief.
Stop Beating Yourself Up and Move Forward

One important lesson I learned is to not beat myself up because of my health challenges. Dealing with a chronic condition like type 2 diabetes is a continuous process of growth and adaptation. It's normal to face setbacks, experience cravings, make mistakes, or feel discouraged at times. Instead of dwelling on the problem, focus on doing whatever it takes to turn things around for good. Be kind to yourself, practice self-compassion, and celebrate each step forward, no matter how small.
Also, whatever your beliefs, know that there is a plan for you, and trust that you have the strength to overcome the obstacles in your path. Leaning on my faith strengthened me during the rough days.

sections.heading: Make the Shift
content: Practically speaking, changing our eating habits, incorporating regular exercise, and shedding excess weight can play a role in improving our health.

content_blocks.text: Practically speaking, changing our eating habits, incorporating regular exercise, and shedding excess weight can play a role in improving our health.

content: By the way, I lost over 80 pounds in less than a year and was able to send type 2 into remission. I’m no longer on medication, and I feel great!
So let me summarize the strategies and mindsets that helped me make the shift.
bullets: Acceptance: Accepting the diagnosis is the first step toward regaining control over your health. Embracing your circumstances can empower you to make positive changes.

Education: Empower yourself with knowledge about type 2 diabetes, its causes, and the impact of lifestyle choices on how it can progress or be sent into remission potentially. Understanding the condition can fuel your determination to take charge of your health.

Support system: Seek out a supportive network of family, friends, and health care professionals who can provide guidance, encouragement, and understanding during your journey. Even if it feels difficult, reach out, and share your experience with those who care about you.
Lifestyle changes: Embrace a transformation in your eating habits. Choose whole, unprocessed foods, emphasizing lean proteins, fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.

Regular exercise: Integrate physical activity into your daily routine, starting with small, manageable steps and gradually increasing intensity and duration. Exercise not only aids in weight loss but also enhances energy levels and overall well-being.

Mindset shift: Change your perspective on food, seeing it as nourishment for your body rather than a source of comfort. Practice mindfulness and self-reflection to overcome food addiction or emotional attachment to unhealthy eating habits.

Persistence and patience: Reversing type 2 diabetes is a gradual process that requires perseverance and patience. Staying committed to your lifestyle changes can lead to remarkable transformations. Don't give up, even when things get tough.

content: In his book, Strength to Love, Martin Luther King Jr. wrote, "The ultimate measure of a man is not where he stands in moments of comfort and convenience, but where he stands at times of challenge and controversy."
So, my friend, love yourself, stand tall, and stay focused!
